newsitem.title: DENMARK: Jyske Bank still sees good whole year 1996.
newsitem.headline: Jyske Bank still sees good whole year 1996.

text.p: Denmark's fourth biggest bank, Jyske Bank posted on Wednesday better than expected first nine-month 1996 profits, 13 percent up on the same period last year, but left unchanged forecasts for its full year result.

Describing the result as "satisfactory", Jyske reported a pre-tax and extraordinary result for 1996's first nine months of 820 million crowns ($141.2 million) , compared to the same 1995 period's 723 million crowns and analysts' average expectations of 795 million.
"We expect a result for the whole year before tax, extraordinary items and securities in the region of 650-750 million crowns," the bank said in a statement.

"The bank's performance for the year's first three quarters was broadly as budgeted and our earlier expectations for full year core earnings before provisions within the 950 million-1.050 billion crown range still hold," it said.
Jyske said it expected losses and bad debt provisions for the whole year in the region of 300-350 million crowns, compared to 1995's 382 million crowns.
The bank had record net profits in 1995 of 725 million crowns compared to the previous year's 90 million, with the pre-tax and extraordinary items result at 961 million crowns.
This year's lower full year expectations are attributed in part to expected lower securities and foreign exchange results.
Jyske Bank is the only major Danish bank to issue quarterly results. --Chris Follett, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33969652 ($ = 5.805 Danish Crowns)
